title: 109_hr5166
content: The "Independent Pharmacy Protection Act of 2006" is aimed at improving Medicare prescription drug plan payments to pharmacies. The "Independent Pharmacy Protection Act of 2006" aims to improve Medicare prescription drug plan payments to pharmacies by providing options for direct deposit payments and increased dispensing fees for generic drugs. The "Independent Pharmacy Protection Act of 2006" aims to improve Medicare prescription drug plan payments to pharmacies by providing options for direct deposit payments and increased dispensing fees for generic drugs. Payment of dispensing fees by the plan to participating pharmacies for covered part D drugs dispensed, with prompt payments to smaller pharmacies. The plan requires payment to pharmacies within 10 days of receiving the claim. Dispensing fees for generic drugs are increased to encourage their use. The plan mandates timely payment to pharmacies, with dispensing fees for generic drugs incentivized by being at least 50% higher than brand name drugs, capped at $10. Brand name drug dispensing fees are protected from reduction. The section ensures that the dispensing fee for brand name drugs at participating pharmacies cannot be reduced below the fee paid on the date of the enactment of the Independent Pharmacy Protection Act of 2006, with the Secretary having the authority to waive this prohibition in certain cases. The section prohibits reducing the dispensing fee for brand name drugs at participating pharmacies below the fee paid on the date of the enactment of the Independent Pharmacy Protection Act of 2006, with the Secretary having the authority to waive this prohibition in certain cases. Additionally, non-disputed claims are defined as those without defects or improprieties that prevent timely payment under this part. The provisions of section 1860D-12(b)(4) regarding pharmacy payments apply to contracts with Medicare Advantage organizations. The amendments made by this Act will apply to plan years starting on or after the enactment date.
